I'm an American student learning Spanish right now and I think all 
languages are hard, some are harder than others depending on where you're 
coming from.  Vocabulary-wise it's very easy to go from English to Spanish. 
 Grammar-wise, not so much.  However, I also speak Hebrew, and while those 
languages are not similar per se, I think knowing how different another 
language can be really opened my mind to learning yet another one.  It's 
not that hard to bend my mind around new grammar structure rules when I 
already know how weird Hebrew can be, and how idioms don't make sense in 
other languages literally but they do in context and when you know them.

+Brian Gonzalez Actually the majority of the people in the Americas speak 
Spanish than any other language. The second language is English, third is 
Portuguese and fourth French. So the primary Language in the continent is 
Spanish. However you are right to a certain point by saying that north, 
central, and south Americans know English. Some do know English but not 
all. Many Spanish speakers from Spanish speaking countries have a hard time 
maintaining it. The reason is they have one official language without a co 
language. Therefore they have no need to learn or maintain a second with 
practice or everyday living. Unlike here in the U.S we have no official 
language so those who are bilingual find it more easier to maintain other 
languages mostly Spanish since it's spoken in the U.S side by side with 
English in everyday living.

repeat after someone :)

I think English people find it a bit hard, because English has roots in 
Germanic (  and Saxon and Nordic language groups ) whereas the Spanish ( as 
well as  Italian, Slavic languages etc . ) originate  form Latin, and the 
two groups have completely different grammar, though the tenses are 
similar, given.

English people do not have noun declension, nor are the nouns, pronouns and 
adjectives affected by gender, for example. They find it next to impossible 
to grasp the concept, which is only natural and understandable.

For example, they would say he wolf, or she wolf, whereas a Hispanic 
person, speaking Spanish would say: a lobo, or la loba :)

comments.author: LeeEL Y

comments.text:
Mira lo que hace la mayoria de los extranjeros es pedir a los demás que 
hablen un poco mas despacio debido a que están aprendiendo español y se les 
dificulta un poco. Eso lo podrías hacer. 

Te recomiendo que veas videos en español acerca de algo que te guste. 
Pintar, ciencia, física o lo que sea. 
También puedes bajar una aplicación que se llama duolingo y te ayuda a 
aprender y practicar diferentes idiomas. E incluso podrías bajar un 
traductor a tu celular. Todo esto lo hago yo para aprender ingles y me ha 
servido muy bien.
Y para practicar mejor, puedes meterte a chats online y asi lo prácticas 
con hablantes nativos y pierdes los nervios.
Espero haberte ayudado y si tienes duda o algo, aqui estoy.
comments.author: blueguitar77

comments.text:
+blueguitar77 Muchas gracias :)  Pero la verdad es que puedo escribir mejor 
que puedo hablar... hablar es la más difícil.  Es cierto que, cuándo 
escribo, comunico bien.  Hay errores, pero la gente puede entenderme.  Pero 
cuándo hablo, hablo así: "Ho-hola, me llamo LeeEl, me gusta... eh... l-leer 
y... y puedo, ¿cómo se dice? ¿Recomendarte? Un libro..."  Y que alguien 
habla conmigo, usualmente hablan rápido, y mi respuesta es "¡¡¿¿Qué??!!".  

Jaja me molesta mucho.  ¿Tienes recomendaciones de películas, libros 
fáciles, canciones, etc. en español para mí?  Quiero practicar.
comments.author: LeeEL Y
